comments.commentBody:
RL trots out his tired conservative cant masked as reason once again. Note the absence of a single piece of evidence in his post, as compared to Mr. Krugman's specific reference to academic studies proving the effectiveness of food stamps. In his strangely convoluted second and third sentences he seems to be arguing that the elderly no longer suffer from real want, but then abruptly shifts to an odd conclusion that those who argue for compassion also argue that helping people undermines self-reliance. What? It seems he simply wants to cram the familiar conservative totems in here somewhere, regardless.

As for his claim about the major difference between liberal and conservative principles, his framing of the argument is off-base. Reasonable liberals know full well that removing all fear and want is impossible. They simply want to help those who are in immediate need. Conservatives do believe differently: they don't want to help. And all of this enables him to ignore one of Mr. Krugman's major points--that most SNAP recipients are children or elderly --and fall back on disproven claims that people using food stamps are lazy slacker adults who don't want to work. His argument is one of denial and evasion.
Private relief agencies are more efficient than government programs.  That's why we contribute to private relief agencies far more than your average pro-government type.

Many individuals who benefit from SNAP are those working in the minimum wage bracket, some of whom are now attempting to bargain for better wages for their efforts. Nutrition and healthcare are prerequistes that allow children to avail of education benefits, which you seem to support. The marginal benefit of a dollar spent on those in real need of it is far greater than continuing to promote rent seeking behaviors, such as continuing to subsidize big agriculture. That is a better example of abuse of public funds IMO. There will always be people who abuse any welfare program. As unethical as that is, reducing benefits in the current economic climate such as this, will also hurt those who genuinely need it.

Do you really believe that the sudden increase in welfare participation rates since the onset of the Great Recession is due to a dramatic increase in indolence? The track record of the Republicans in mitigating the effects of the recession have been abysmal.

How can that possibly be?

Bryan, totally agree with you. Like voting sitting on a jury is a privilege that shouldn't be given to anyone who hasn't earned this right. Maybe another lesson to be gotten from Russia. They seem to be teaching us now.

Interesting responses. My point is that being a citizen of the US, is the critical question. It means that you have foresworn all other allegiances, to, as I recall was part of the oath then, all "foreign princes and potentates", and sworn to protect and defend the US.

The interview portion of the process in my case was interesting in that the interviewer posed the question of what would happen in the event of a clash of warfare between Ireland, my country of birth, and Great Britain, if my USAR unit was activated to come to the aid of the British. I was surprised by the question; satisfied him with the answer that I would do my duty.

Non citizens have not made a commitment to the nation therefore in my view they might as well be tourists as it were, without the any investment in the life of the country. I was never asked in any of the jury pools on which I served if I was a citizen and never heard that question addressed to any other prospective jurors. The selection process, most especially in the murder case, seemed to be totally random.

Bryan, you were a "permanent resident", paid taxes, obeyed laws, studied to be naturalized. I'd have loved to have you on my jury, as a peer. You have brains, education, experience, interest in American society and justice? Then c'mon in, I'd say. I am a permanent resident of Canada and would serve any time, if called. My degrees, work, and professional contributions to Canada surely equal the ones I'd have after becoming a Can. citizen. They don't get bigger, do they? Judicial Viagra? Nah.

As a legal immigrant, Mr Keller, your subject has a special attraction, since I have been on three jury pools, and like you, not chosen to serve. All were criminal cases, a murder accusation, and two drug cases, in Chester County, PA. in 36 years and I was excused on each occasion. As a small business person, serving on a jury would have been a major financial sacrifice, though I was willing and able to serve.

Since I became a citizen in 1969, and then spent days in the pool at the Chester County Court House, speaking with and listening to the probable peers in the pool, I am absolutely opposed to the California proposal that non citizens, legal or illegal , be appointed as members of a jury of "peers", in any circumstances.

The question of peers is vital; the good and decent people whom I encountered on those panels were indeed peers in the classical sense; they represented a cross section of the population of the county and were for the most part willing, though mostly fearful, to serve. The main objection expressed was that they would not understand the law and would be prone to make a bad decision, and regret that decision.

The probability that a juror, most particularly an illegal immigrant, or a non citizen of the US, likely unfamiliar with the history and traditions of our nation would be chosen to sit on a jury charged with sitting in judgement on you, and most certainly, on me, is totally unacceptable. Americans are likely highly unwilling to allow this.

But the right wingnuts attend institutions like Patrick Henry "University" and Oral Roberts "University", and are convinced that the education they received there far superior to any they might receive at a commie liberal institution like Berkley or Princeton, or any State Supported Institution.
You mean they wouldn't just slink away and starve to death somewhere? Isn't that what the Republicans want? It sure seems like it. GOP: The real "death panel".

Whatever "savings" there would be to the government would be offset by a whole bevy of new costs of law enforcement, criminal justice expenses, etc.  Moreover, a significant source of income for many grocery stores would be replaced by losses, since the same food would be now be stolen.

No one can fund a company, and pay employees, with free products. The fact that these companies are so well funded and, in the case of Google, insanely profitable, is that there is tremendous value in the information they collect from people, when it is cross referenced with other data that is readily available.

Certain freedoms are great, such as the freedom of speech and religion.  But as Professor Krugman points out, the word freedom is often, especially for conservatives, a cover for greed and exploitation of the weak.  They believe in freedom to be hungry, to be unhealthy, to be poor, to be uneducated, to have unclean air and water, and the freedom be controlled by corporations and the rich. Two of the freedoms that FDR wanted to ensure are revealing: freedom from want, and freedom from fear.  These vital freedoms entail  the resolute use of government, something that Republicans today don't understand or don't want to understand.

Back about 1960 when citizen's band radios were permitted, there was indeed a problem. Unlike hams, where there was a lot of training about Radio Frequency Interference for getting a license, and peer pressure for following the rules that said you needed the captain's permission to transmit aboard a ship or plane, untrained CB users could be a hazard to avionics that used, in those days, superhetrodyne beat-frequency methods in both receivers and transmitter circuits..Even a receiver could interfere with another receiver because of the beat frequencies that it locally broadcast.

But fifty years of electronics progress has changed most of that vulnerability. And we now have fifty years of aviation experience that comes from passengers' electronics inadvertently left on in flight. I'd bet that there are more than a half-dozen left on per flight. There are not many aviation incidents that can be blamed on avionics overwhelmed by something mysterious.

You'd think that the airlines, always trying to emphasize the excellence of their safety equipment, would be telling the regulators that they no longer need these traditional regulations. The notion that your kid's electronic toys could crash the plane is not exactly reassuring to the passengers. It's possible, but hardly probable.

The physics you seem to be referring to is Gauss's Law, stating that the net charge inside a closed conducting surface is zero.  The hull of a metal jetliner is a good approximation to such a surface but this physics would not prevent a strong radio signal from a device inside the aircraft from interfering with vulnerable avionics also inside the aircraft.

Your suggestion is not supported by professionals in this industry. There are many "absurdities" about air travel - why they ask if you packed your bag, why tampering with the lavatory smoke detector is more of a crime than tampering with other parts, etc - but the concern about electromagnetic and electronic interference is not one of them.

You seriously misunderstand wireless communication if you think there is no chance that a malfunctioning device can interfere with on-board electronics.

Must you have your iphone on at all times? Can't you take this tiny break? It's literally the least you can do.
it is absurd that there is even a ban to begin with. net charge in a cylinder is always zero. people who have taken a physics class would clearly understand this.
